intro: Meyerocactus horizonthalonius subsp. nicholii, commonly known as the desert hedgehog cactus, is a rare and unique cactus species native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States. It is characterized by its cylindrical stems that are covered in dense, spiny areoles, giving it a distinctive, prickly appearance. The plant produces yellow flowers during the spring and summer months, which are typically short-lived but attract pollinators such as bees and moths. It thrives in well-drained soils and requires minimal water, making it well adapted to harsh desert environments. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
